Blog.post: I've subscribed to the urlLink JXTA and urlLink CHORD mailing list few weeks ago...

JXORD is my Final year project which I am doing for my undergraduate degree. The JXORD name is derived from combining JXTA and CHORD. Its a distributed p2p file sharing app based on JXTA and CHORD. urlLink JXTA is peer to peer framework and set of protocols supported by Sun Micro Systems. JXTA will enable me to build my, basic communication network. CHORD will be my lookup service; solving the problem of cutting down the overhead for searching. urlLink CHORD is a research project carried by the urlLink Parallel and Distributed Operating Systems (PDOS) group at the Computer Science Dept, MIT. My intial objective for the system will be to : 1. Users to search for files in the JXORD network based on one keyword 2. Download files, after searching them. 3. Nodes can join and leave, maintaing the integrity of the JXORD network. 4. JXORD should be scalable.

As of today.. things are not going too well with JXORD.. I have given up the idea of implementing CHORD as a seperate module for JXTA.. as I figured CHORD is going to be a core service of JXORD and its a overkill to publish advertisments for CHORD itself. May be I am wrong.. Pax

The Matrix and Buddhism I'm not a fan of The Matrix, but I came across this interesting artical and thought I should share it with you Although the presence of Christian themes is strong in The Matrix, the influence of Buddhism is equally powerful and evident. Indeed, the basic philosophical premises that drive major plot points would be nearly incomprehensible without a little background understanding of Buddhism and Buddhist doctrines. Does this force the conclusion that The Matrix and The Matrix Reloaded are Buddhist movies? The most obvious and fundamental Buddhist theme can be found in the basic principle that, in the world of the Matrix films, what most people think of as "reality" is actually a computer-generated simulation. This appears to align closely with the Buddhist doctrine that the world was we know it is maya, illusion, which we must break out of in order to achieve enlightenment. Indeed, according to Buddhism the biggest problem that faces humanity is our inability to see through this illusion. urlLink [more]

Westheimer's Rule For all those ppl who try to be optimistic.... To estimate the time it takes to do a task: estimate the time you think it should take, multiply by two and change the unit of measure to the next highest unit. Thus, we allocate two days for a one hour task That means for a 9 month project... 9 months * 2 = 18 months 18 months converted into the next highest unit = 18 years lol Packs!!!

Upaka Here's how my name came to be ( urlLink Source ) An Ájivaka whom the Buddha met on his way between Gayá and the Bodhi Tree, after he set out from Isipatana for the preaching of the First Sermon. Upaka questioned the Buddha on his attainments, and when the Buddha told him what he had accomplished he asked the Buddha if he were "Anantajina." When the Buddha acknowledged it, Upaka shook his bead saying, "It may be so, friend," and went along by another road (J.i.81; Vin.i.8; M.i.170-1; DhA.iv.71-2). It is said (DA.ii.471) that the Buddha walked all the way from the Bodhi Tree to Isipatana - instead of flying through the air, as is the custom of Buddhas - because he wished to meet Upaka. After this meeting Upaka went to the Vankahára country and there, having fallen desperately in love with Cápá, the daughter of a huntsman who looked after him, starved for seven days and in the end persuaded the huntsman to give her to him in marriage. For a living, Upaka hawked about the flesh brought by the huntsman. In due course Cápá bore him a son, Subhadda. When the baby cried, Cápá sang to him saying, "Upaka's son, ascetic's son, game-dealer's boy, don't cry," thus mocking her husband. In exasperation he told her of his friend Anantajina, but she did not stop teasing him. One day, in spite of her attempts to keep him, he left her and went to the Buddha at Sávatthi. The Buddha, seeing him coming, gave orders that anyone asking for Anantajina should be brought to him. Having learnt from Upaka his story, the Buddha had him admitted to the Order. As a result of his meditation, Upaka became an anágámí and was reborn in the Avihá heaven (ThigA.220ff; MA.i.388f. Upaka's story is also given in SnA.i.258ff, with several variations in detail). The Samyutta Nikáya (i.35, 60) records a visit paid to the Buddha by Upaka and six other beings born in Avihá. According to the Majjhima Commentary (i.389), Upaka became an arahant as soon as he was born in Avihá.
